variant.question: The aeroplane outside air temperature probe measures the:

options.text: static air temperature, this must be corrected for compressibility effects to obtain the total air temperature.
total air temperature, this must be corrected for compressibility effects to obtain the static air temperature.
total air temperature, this must be corrected for ram rise and recovery factor to obtain the static air temperature.
static air temperature, this must be corrected for ram rise and recovery factor to obtain the total air temperature.

variant.question: What does 470 ft/min equal to?
If the static source of an altimeter becomes blocked during a descent the instrument will:

options.text: indicate height when the subscale setting is on QNH.
continue to display the reading at which the blockage occurred.

variant.question:
The output data from an ADC are used by:

1 – Transponder   
2 – EFIS via the symbol generator   
3 – Automatic Flight Control System (AFCS)

The combination that regroups all of the correct statements is:
The following parameters must be determined first before displaying the Mach number:

options.text: Static pressure and outside air temperature.
Outside air temperature and air density.

variant.question:
An Air-Data Inertial Reference Unit (ADIRU) has separate controls for switching the air-data and inertial reference part ON or OFF. The pilot accidentally switches OFF the incorrect system when following a procedure to address a fault. What is correct?

(For this question, only consider the system as a standalone part NOT including other aircraft systems that may also be affected by the scenario.)

1\. If the air-data part is switched OFF instead of the inertial reference part, there is NO effect as the data can be recovered when the air-data part is switched back on.   
 2\. If the air-data part is switched OFF instead of the inertial reference part, the function is severely limited as the air-data part CANNOT be initialised when switched back ON.   
 3\. If the inertial reference part is switched OFF instead of the air-data part, the function is severely limited as the inertial reference part CANNOT be fully re-aligned when switched back ON.   
 4\. If the inertial reference part is switched OFF instead of the air-data part, there is NO effect as the data can be recovered when the inertial reference part is switched back on.
Consider a barometric VSI with a non-linear scale. What does this mean?

options.text: A small ROC or ROD is displayed more accurately than a large one.
The ROC scale is more accurate than the ROD scale.
The increments between zero and the maximum value are equally spaced.
The ROD scale is more accurate than the ROC scale.

variant.question: An aeroplane is descending from FL 390 to ground level at maximum speed. The limit(s) in speed is (are):

options.text: MMO only during all the descent.
initially MMO, then VMO below a given flight level.
VMO only during all the descent.
initially VMO, then MMO below a given flight level.

variant.question: A leak in the total pressure line of a non-pressurised aircraft to an airspeed indicator would cause it to:

options.text: underread in a climb and over-read in a descent.
overread in a climb and under-read in a descent.

variant.question: An airspeed indicator displays:
Assuming the flight level and Mach number remain constant, when the OAT decreases:

options.text: CAS remains constant and TAS increases.
CAS remains constant and TAS decreases.

variant.question: The white arc of a conventional Airspeed Indicator (ASI) corresponds to the…

options.text: Lowest part of the caution speed range.

variant.question:
How can a pilot recognize an unreliable speed condition?

1\. Vibration on elevator   
 2\. Vibration on the floor   
 3\. Vibration on the pedals   
 4\. Pitch up attitude   
 5\. Indication on EFIS
After an aircraft has passed through a volcanic cloud, the inlet of the pitot tube is blocked. The pilot begins a stabilised descent and finds that the IAS:
The “barber pole” on an ASI indicates:

options.text: The higher of VNE and VMO.
The lower of VNE and VMO.

variant.question: How is the indication of Mach number obtained? From:

options.text: A kind of echo sound comparing velocity of sound with indicated speed.
An ordinary airspeed indicator scaled for Mach numbers instead of knots.
Indicated speed (IAS) compared with true air speed (TAS) from the air data computer.
Indicated speed and altitude using a speed indicator equipped with an altimeter type aneroid.

variant.question: An aeroplane is approaching the runway for landing. During the flare, it stalls without warning and experiences a hard landing. What factor could explain this?

options.text: The pitot tube was blocked, resulting in false airspeed indications.
The AoA sensor vane was stuck in one position.
The stall warning light was defective.
The stick shaker motor was burnt out.

variant.question: Which option best describes the operation principle of an Air Data Computer (ADC)?

options.text: Raw data generated by the aerodynamic probes (static pressure, pitot) are digitised by data processing modules; the ADC uses these binary values to calculate the air data (pressure altitude, speeds, temperatures)

Data from classical analogue instruments are used (altimeter, airspeed indicator, temperature probes) and are fed into the ADC; the ADC collects air data (pressure altitude, speeds, temperature) for other systems
Data generated by the IRS are used by the ADC to calculate the air data (altitude, speeds)
Data are generated by accelerometers (in the three dimensions) and are used by ADC to calculate the air data (pressure altitude, speeds)

variant.question: If the static source of an airspeed indicator becomes blocked during a descent the instrument will:

options.text: continue to indicate the speed applicable to that at the time of the blockage

variant.question: The altimeter of an aircraft provides indications from 0 - 30 000 ft. The aircraft is on a position of known elevation at the airfield and the altimeter is set to the local QNH. The altimeter will read the elevation of that point:

options.text: plus the height of the altimeter from the ground with a +/- 80 ft tolerance
plus the height of the altimeter from the ground with a +/- 60 ft tolerance

variant.question: What happens when speed becomes unreliable?

options.text: Vibration on the floor and pedals.
It is shown on the PFD, "Speed disagreement".
From the horizontal stabiliser, the pilots will receive some kind of vibration through flight controls.

variant.question: Angle of attack vane is damaged during the flight. Which of the following will be directly impacted?
During climb with a rate of 500 feet per minute the static ports of the aircraft become blocked. For the rest of the flight, the vertical speed indications will…

options.text: constantly indicates a 500 feet per minute climb.
return to, and indicate, zero feet per minute.

variant.question: Due to an aircraft upset, the pilot's instrument scan is disrupted. When he/she next looks at the instruments, he/she sees that the airspeed needle has moved from within the range of the yellow arc to beyond that indicated by a red line. These speed markings represent:

options.text: The normal speed range and the flaps extended speed.
The caution range and the normal operating speed limit.
The caution range and the never exceed speed.
The normal speed range and the never exceed speed.

variant.question:
In a mechanical instrument, the VMO/MMO pointer (barberpole) connects to which of the items listed below?

1\. Aneroid capsule   
2\. Differential pressure capsule   
3\. Temperature-sensitive capsule

Which of these statements about failures of different ADIRU parts are correct or incorrect?

1\. If an ADC is accidentally switched off during flight, it is possible to turn it back on.   
 2\. If an IRS is accidentally switched off during flight, it can be problematic as it is not possible to realign it during flight.
The airspeed, altitude, and angle of attack are fed to the ADIRU by the \_\_\_\_\_.
The limits of the yellow arc (caution speed range) of an airspeed indicator are:

options.text: VFE for the lower limit and VNE for the upper limit.
VLE for the lower limit and VNE for the upper limit.
VNO for the lower limit and VNE for the upper limit.
VLO for the lower limit and VNE for the upper limit.

variant.question: The Mach Meter is subject to position error. This error varies with:

options.text: Mach number and angle of attack.

variant.question: The limits of the white scale of an airspeed indicator are:

options.text: VS0 for the lower limit and VLE for the upper limit
VS0 for the lower limit and VFE for the upper limit
VS1 for the lower limit and VFE for the upper limit
VS1 for the lower limit and VLE for the upper limit

variant.question: If flying an aircraft not equipped with automatic temperature correction, to which altitudes should the PIC apply temperature correction?

options.text: at MDH/MDA or DH/DA and step-down fixes inside the final approach fix (FAF).
only at the step-down fixes inside the final approach fix (FAF).

variant.question:
If the ADC fails, which of the following instruments related to the pitot-static instruments are affected?

1\. Air Speed Indicator  
2\. Vertical Speed Indicator  
3\. Altimeter  
4\. Attitude indicator
Most modern transport aircraft have three Air Data Inertial Reference Units (ADIRUs). Each ADIRU combines an IRS with ....., which sends barometric altitude and TAS information to the IRS.

options.text: an Attitude and Heading Reference System.

variant.question: An aircraft is flying with an IVSI when another aircraft in front, same level and route, reports moderate turbulence. How does this affect the IVSI?

An air data computer

1– supplies GS and drift angle   
2 – determines TAT and true altitude   
3 – receives static pressure and total pressure   
4 – supplies TAS to the INS computer   
5 – determines Mach number and OAT.

The combination that regroups all of the correct statements is:
What happens to TAS and ROC if an aircraft climbs at constant CAS of 300kt and a vertical speed of 2 000 ft/min?
ATC asks you to “expedite climb” in departure. Which speed should you use, and how is it indicated?

options.text: Best RATE of climb speed. Blue line.
Best angle of climb speed. Blue line.
Best rate of climb speed. Green arc.
Best angle of climb speed. White arc.

variant.question: How many capsules can you find in a sensitive altimeter?
During a preflight inspection of a multi engined aircraft, you notice that the AOA sensor is damaged. Which systems are affected?
How is the risk of stalling affected if an aeroplane climbs at constant Mach number?

options.text: It is unaffected, as the TAS will remain the same.
It decreases, as the TAS of the aircraft is increasing.
It increases up to around FL200, and then decreases.
It increases, as the TAS of the aircraft is decreasing.

variant.question: The Mach number is the:

options.text: CAS divided by the local speed of sound.
EAS divided by the local speed of sound.
IAS divided by the local speed of sound.
TAS divided by the local speed of sound.

variant.question: The captain's ASI reads a 5 kt difference from the co-pilot’s ASI. What additional action can the pilots perform?

options.text: They can change the ADC readout.
There is nothing the flight crew can do as the difference is within limits.
They should divert as soon as possible.
The groundspeed can be verified from the INS/GNSS.

variant.question: Which of the following systems uses output data from the Air Data Computer?

The outputs of an ADC can be used by:
During the cruise at FL400, the pitot tubes of your aircraft become blocked by volcanic ash. After starting a descent, what should you be aware of? The airspeed display will…

options.text: It is located on the tail of the aircraft.
It is a small vane on the leading edge of the wing.
It is located on the side of the fuselage.
It is a small radar dish on top of the cockpit.

variant.question: In which of the following conditions are TAS and EAS equal?

options.text: P: 1 013.25 hPa, OAT: 15°C and TAS < 200 kt
P: 1 013.25 hPa, OAT: 15°C and TAS > 200 kt

variant.question: What does the logarithmic scale of a Vertical Speed Indicator (VSI) mean?

options.text: A small rate of change is displayed more accurately than a large rate of change.
A large rate of change is displayed more accurately than a small rate of change.
The VSI only reads correctly under ISA conditions.
All rates of climb and descent are displayed with the same accuracy.

variant.question: The response time of a vertical speed detector may be decreased by adding a:

options.text: correction based on an acceleration sensor.

variant.question:
How could a pilot notice an airspeed unreliable condition?

1\. Flight controls vibrations  
2\. Floor vibrations  
3\. Message on the PFD  
4\. Different airspeed indications on the ASIs  
5\. Buffeting
If you are flying through turbulence, you can expect the IVSI to (1) \_\_\_\_\_. You should (2) \_\_\_\_\_ small fluctuations.
What feature makes the IVSI a better instrument?

options.text: It uses accelerometers to make the reaction time quicker.
It relies on mechanical linkages to sense changes in air pressure.
It uses GPS signals to calculate vertical speed.
Accelerometers change the pressure in the capsule.

variant.question: The altimeter indicates 16 000 ft with a subscale-setting of 1013,25 mb. QNH is 993 hPa. OAT is -3°C. The pressure altitude of the aircraft is:
EAS is equal to:

options.text: IAS corrected for position, instrument and compressibility errors.

variant.question: Give the meaning of the acronym PUDSOD.

options.text: Previously used DME source of distance measurement
Pitot underreads in descent, static overreads in descent
Performance unit drive system on drive

variant.question:
What input data is required by an AOA sensor?

1\. Autothrust mode   
2\. Thrust   
3\. Flaps   
4\. Slats   
5\. CAS
When flying steadily at FL180 with the AP engaged you suspect erroneous altimeter indications. What could you check to know which altimeter delivers a correct indication?
If the pilot increases the reference pressure using the sub-scale setting knob, the altitude indicated by the altimeter:
